title: The Intermediate Value Theorem
text: The Intermediate Value Theorem: Let f be continuous over a closed, bounded interval [a,b]. If $$z$$ is any real number between f(a) and f(b), then there is a number c in [a,b] satisfying $$f(c)=z$$.\n##figure1.gif##

title: The Intermediate Value Theorem Part $$2$$
text: Since $$f(x)=x-cos(x)$$ is continuous over $$(-\infty,\infty)$$, it is continuous over any closed interval of the form [a,b].

title: The Intermediate Value Theorem Part $$3$$
text: If you can find an interval [a,b] such that f(a) and f(b) have opposite signs, you can use the Intermediate Value Theorem to conclude there must be a real number c in (a,b) that satisfies $$f(c)=0$$.
